properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving low pressure system will continue to bring significant rain to the Churchill area today along with strong gusty northerly winds. Rainfall totals for Monday afternoon through early this morning have reached 81 mm and a further 10 mm is expected before tapering off late Thursday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Tropical Depression Erin. The next information statement will be issued by 09:00 a.m. ADT. Tropical Depression Erin is tracking northeastward toward the Maritimes. Erin is expected to transition to a post-tropical system well before it reaches southwestern Nova Scotia this evening. Erin will bring heavy rain to much of the region today, and strong gusty winds to parts of Nova Scotia tonight. 1. Summary of basic information at 03:00 a.m. ADT. Location: Near 36.2 North 71.9 West. About distance 345 kilometres east-northeast of Cape Hatteras NC. Maximum sustained winds: 56 kilometres per hour. Present movement: North-northeast at 33 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 1004 millibars. 2. Public weather impacts and warnings summary. Tropical Depression Erin is expected to transition to a post-tropical system by the time it enters Canadian waters later today. Rain associated with a trough of low pressure approaching from the west will spread over the western Maritimes this morning. As Erin approaches, some of its moisture will feed into this trough and likely enhance the rain intensity associated with it. The heavier rain and strongest winds associated directly with post-tropical Erin should reach the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia later this evening or early Friday morning. a. Wind. Some gusty winds will likely accompany post-tropical Erin, especially to those areas just to the right of its track as it crosses Nova Scotia later tonight. It is not expected that these winds will reach warning criteria (i.e. gusts to 90 km/h or higher), but could still be strong enough to cause isolated power outages and minor damage, especially given that trees are still in full leaf. b. Rainfall. The combination of Post-Tropical Erin and its interaction with the trough of low pressure crossing the region today will combine to produce significant rainfall. Rainfall will likely meet or exceed warning criteria (50 mm or more in 24 hours) in parts of the Maritimes, especially those areas just north and west of Erin's track. Some isolated locations in these areas could possibly see total rainfall amounts in excess of 100 mm before the rain ends later Friday morning. Rainfall warnings are now in effect for southeastern New Brunswick and may extended to parts of Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island this morning. c. Surge/Waves. Significant storm surge and coastal impacts from high waves are not expected. After midnight into Friday morning, waves near 4 metres will spread from west to east along the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia and will break higher along the beaches. Rip currents could also be an issue, and the public should exercise caution near the coast. 3. Marine weather impacts and warnings summary. Gale warnings are in effect for most Maritimes waters near and to the right of Erin's track through the marine district, where gale force southerlies up to 40 knots are possible. Forecaster(s): Borgel ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-08-30T11:47:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-29T05:48:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0768326673.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Post tropical storm Erin will cross western Nova Scotia tonight and then track into the Gulf of St. Lawrence Friday morning. Rain at times heavy and gusty winds are expected across most of Nova Scotia as it moves through. Total rainfall amounts of up to 45 mm are expected for the South Shore and central Nova Scotia. Lesser amounts are expected across eastern areas of the province. Should the track shift further east, rainfall warnings may be expanded. Southeasterly wind gusts to 60 or 70 km/h are expected to develop this evening and overnight. Winds will shift to the west and then diminish Friday morning. In addition, waves near 4 metres will spread from west to east along the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia and will break higher along the beaches. Rip currents may also be an issue, and the public should exercise caution near the coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-30T02:23:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-29T18:24:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1859770306.2019

properties.Summary:

Total accumulations between 30-50 mm are expected by Friday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Post tropical storm Erin will track across Prince Edward Island Friday morning. Rain at times heavy and gusty winds are expected as it moves through. Total rainfall amounts of up to 40 mm are currently expected over Kings County. Strong southeasterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will develop overnight and then diminish Friday morning as winds shift to the west. At this time, there remains some uncertainty in the track of the system and should it shift eastward, a rainfall warning may be issued. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Erin. The next information statement will be issued by 09:00 p.m. ADT. Erin, now a Post-tropical system, will continue tracking northeastward towards the Maritimes. Erin is bringing heavy rain to much of the region today, and strong gusty winds to parts of Nova Scotia tonight. 1. Summary of basic information at 03:00 p.m. ADT. Location: Near 40.2 North 68.0 West. About distance 431 kilometres south-southwest of Yarmouth NS. Maximum sustained winds: 65 kilometres per hour. Present movement: North-northeast at 39 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 1003 millibars. 2. Public weather impacts and warnings summary. Rain associated with a trough of low pressure approaching from the west will continue to spread across the Maritimes. As Post-tropical Erin approaches, some of its moisture will feed into this trough and likely enhance the rain intensity associated with it. The heavier rain and strongest winds associated directly with Post-Tropical Erin should reach the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia later this evening or early Friday morning. a. Wind. Some gusty winds will likely accompany Post-tropical Erin, especially to those areas just to the right of its track as it crosses Nova Scotia later tonight. It is not expected that these winds will reach warning criteria (i.e. gusts to 90 km/h or higher), but could still be strong enough to cause isolated power outages and minor damage, especially given that trees are still in full leaf. b. Rainfall. The combination of Post-tropical Erin and its interaction with the trough of low pressure crossing the region today will combine to produce significant rainfall. Rainfall will likely meet or exceed warning criteria (50 mm or more in 24 hours) in parts of the Maritimes, especially those areas just north and west of Erin's track. Some isolated locations in these areas could possibly see total rainfall amounts in excess of 100 mm before the rain ends later Friday morning. Rainfall warnings are now in effect for southern New Brunswick, parts of western and northern Nova Scotia, and western Prince Edward Island. c. Surge/Waves. Significant storm surge and coastal impacts from high waves are not expected. After midnight into Friday morning, waves near 4 metres will spread from west to east along the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia and will break higher along the beaches. Rip currents could also be an issue, and the public should exercise caution near the coast. 3. Marine weather impacts and warnings summary. Gale warnings are in effect for most Maritimes waters near and to the right of Erin's track through the marine district, where gale force southerlies up to 45 knots are possible. Forecaster(s): Mercer ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-08-30T23:04:46-00:00
